class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003col dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf you have previous/other manually installed (= not installed via \u003ccode\u003epip\u003c/code\u003e) version of OpenCV installed (e.g. cv2 module in the root of Python's site-packages), remove it before installation to avoid conflicts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eMake sure that your \u003ccode\u003epip\u003c/code\u003e version is up-to-date (19.3 is the minimum supported version): \u003ccode\u003epip install --upgrade pip\u003c/code\u003e. Check version with \u003ccode\u003epip -V\u003c/code\u003e. For example Linux distributions ship usually with very old \u003ccode\u003epip\u003c/code\u003e versions which cause a lot of unexpected problems especially with the \u003ccode\u003emanylinux\u003c/code\u003e format.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSelect the correct package for your environment:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThere are four different packages (see options 1, 2, 3 and 4 below) and you should \u003cstrong\u003eSELECT ONLY ONE OF THEM\u003c/strong\u003e. Do not install multiple different packages in the same environment. There is no plugin architecture: all the packages use the same namespace (\u003ccode\u003ecv2\u003c/code\u003e). If you installed multiple different packages in the same environment, uninstall them all with \u003ccode\u003epip uninstall\u003c/code\u003e and reinstall only one package.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ea.\u003c/strong\u003e Packages for standard desktop environments (Windows, macOS, almost any GNU/Linux distribution)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eOption 1 - Main modules package: \u003ccode\u003epip install opencv-python\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eOption 2 - Full package (contains both main modules and contrib/extra modules): \u003ccode\u003epip install opencv-contrib-python\u003c/code\u003e (check contrib/extra modules listing from \u003ca href=\"https://docs.opencv.org/master/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eOpenCV documentation\u003c/a\u003e)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eb.\u003c/strong\u003e Packages for server (headless) environments (such as Docker, cloud environments etc.), no GUI library dependencies\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThese packages are smaller than the two other packages above because they do not contain any GUI functionality (not compiled with Qt / other GUI components). This means that the packages avoid a heavy dependency chain to X11 libraries and you will have for example smaller Docker images as a result. You should always use these packages if you do not use \u003ccode\u003ecv2.imshow\u003c/code\u003e et al. or you are using some other package (such as PyQt) than OpenCV to create your GUI.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eOption 3 - Headless main modules package: \u003ccode\u003epip install opencv-python-headless\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eOption 4 - Headless full package (contains both main modules and contrib/extra modules): \u003ccode\u003epip install opencv-contrib-python-headless\u003c/code\u003e (check contrib/extra modules listing from \u003ca href=\"https://docs.opencv.org/master/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eOpenCV documentation\u003c/a\u003e)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eImport the package:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003eimport cv2\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAll packages contain Haar cascade files. \u003ccode\u003ecv2.data.haarcascades\u003c/code\u003e can be used as a shortcut to the data folder. For example:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003ecv2.CascadeClassifier(cv2.data.haarcascades + \"haarcascade_frontalface_default.xml\")\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eRead \u003ca href=\"https://docs.opencv.org/master/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eOpenCV documentation\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eBefore opening a new issue, read the FAQ below and have a look at the other issues which are already open.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eFrequently Asked Questions\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-frequently-asked-questions\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Frequently Asked Questions\" href=\"#frequently-asked-questions\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eQ: Do I need to install also OpenCV separately?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eA: No, the packages are special wheel binary packages and they already contain statically built OpenCV binaries.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eQ: Pip install fails with \u003ccode\u003eModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'skbuild'\u003c/code\u003e?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSince \u003ccode\u003eopencv-python\u003c/code\u003e version 4.3.0.*, \u003ccode\u003emanylinux1\u003c/code\u003e wheels were replaced by \u003ccode\u003emanylinux2014\u003c/code\u003e wheels. If your pip is too old, it will try to use the new source distribution introduced in 4.3.0.38 to manually build OpenCV because it does not know how to install \u003ccode\u003emanylinux2014\u003c/code\u003e wheels. However, source build will also fail because of too old \u003ccode\u003epip\u003c/code\u003e because it does not understand build dependencies in \u003ccode\u003epyproject.toml\u003c/code\u003e. To use the new \u003ccode\u003emanylinux2014\u003c/code\u003e pre-built wheels (or to build from source), your \u003ccode\u003epip\u003c/code\u003e version must be \u0026gt;= 19.3. Please upgrade \u003ccode\u003epip\u003c/code\u003e with \u003ccode\u003epip install --upgrade pip\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eQ: Import fails on Windows: \u003ccode\u003eImportError: DLL load failed: The specified module could not be found.\u003c/code\u003e?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eA: If the import fails on Windows, make sure you have \u003ca href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=48145\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eVisual C++ redistributable 2015\u003c/a\u003e installed. If you are using older Windows version than Windows 10 and latest system updates are not installed, \u003ca href=\"https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/2999226/update-for-universal-c-runtime-in-windows\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eUniversal C Runtime\u003c/a\u003e might be also required.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eWindows N and KN editions do not include Media Feature Pack which is required by OpenCV. If you are using Windows N or KN edition, please install also \u003ca href=\"https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/3145500/media-feature-pack-list-for-windows-n-editions\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eWindows Media Feature Pack\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf you have Windows Server 2012+, media DLLs are probably missing too; please install the Feature called \"Media Foundation\" in the Server Manager. Beware, some posts advise to install \"Windows Server Essentials Media Pack\", but this one requires the \"Windows Server Essentials Experience\" role, and this role will deeply affect your Windows Server configuration (by enforcing active directory integration etc.); so just installing the \"Media Foundation\" should be a safer choice.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf the above does not help, check if you are using Anaconda. Old Anaconda versions have a bug which causes the error, see \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/opencv/opencv-python/issues/36\" data-hovercard-type=\"issue\" data-hovercard-url=\"/opencv/opencv-python/issues/36/hovercard\"\u003ethis issue\u003c/a\u003e for a manual fix.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf you still encounter the error after you have checked all the previous solutions, download \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/lucasg/Dependencies\"\u003eDependencies\u003c/a\u003e and open the \u003ccode\u003ecv2.pyd\u003c/code\u003e (located usually at \u003ccode\u003eC:\\Users\\username\\AppData\\Local\\Programs\\Python\\PythonXX\\Lib\\site-packages\\cv2\u003c/code\u003e) file with it to debug missing DLL issues.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eQ: I have some other import errors?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eA: Make sure you have removed old manual installations of OpenCV Python bindings (cv2.so or cv2.pyd in site-packages).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eQ: Function foo() or method bar() returns wrong result, throws exception or crashes interpreter. What should I do?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eA: The repository contains only OpenCV-Python package build scripts, but not OpenCV itself. Python bindings for OpenCV are developed in official OpenCV repository and it's the best place to report issues. Also please check \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/opencv/opencv/wiki\"\u003eOpenCV wiki\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href=\"https://forum.opencv.org/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ethe official OpenCV forum\u003c/a\u003e before file new bugs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eQ: Why the packages do not include non-free algorithms?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eA: Non-free algorithms such as SURF are not included in these packages because they are patented / non-free and therefore cannot be distributed as built binaries. Note that SIFT is included in the builds due to patent expiration since OpenCV versions 4.3.0 and 3.4.10. See this issue for more info: \u003ca class=\"issue-link js-issue-link\" data-error-text=\"Failed to load title\" data-id=\"359347266\" data-permission-text=\"Title is private\" data-url=\"https://github.com/opencv/opencv-python/issues/126\" data-hovercard-type=\"issue\" data-hovercard-url=\"/opencv/opencv-python/issues/126/hovercard\" href=\"https://github.com/opencv/opencv-python/issues/126\"\u003e#126\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eQ: Why the package and import are different (opencv-python vs. cv2)?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eA: It's easier for users to understand \u003ccode\u003eopencv-python\u003c/code\u003e than \u003ccode\u003ecv2\u003c/code\u003e and it makes it easier to find the package with search engines. \u003ccode\u003ecv2\u003c/code\u003e (old interface in old OpenCV versions was named as \u003ccode\u003ecv\u003c/code\u003e) is the name that OpenCV developers chose when they created the binding generators. This is kept as the import name to be consistent with different kind of tutorials around the internet. Changing the import name or behaviour would be also confusing to experienced users who are accustomed to the \u003ccode\u003eimport cv2\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe aim of this repository is to provide means to package each new \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/opencv/opencv/releases\"\u003eOpenCV release\u003c/a\u003e for the most used Python versions and platforms.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eCI build process\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-ci-build-process\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: CI build process\" href=\"#ci-build-process\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe project is structured like a normal Python package with a standard \u003ccode\u003esetup.py\u003c/code\u003e file.\nThe build process for a single entry in the build matrices is as follows (see for example \u003ccode\u003e.github/workflows/build_wheels_linux.yml\u003c/code\u003e file):\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col start=\"0\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIn Linux and MacOS build: get OpenCV's optional C dependencies that we compile against\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eCheckout repository and submodules\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eOpenCV is included as submodule and the version is updated\nmanually by maintainers when a new OpenCV release has been made\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eContrib modules are also included as a submodule\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFind OpenCV version from the sources\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eBuild OpenCV\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003etests are disabled, otherwise build time increases too much\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ethere are 4 build matrix entries for each build combination: with and without contrib modules, with and without GUI (headless)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eLinux builds run in manylinux Docker containers (CentOS 5)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003esource distributions are separate entries in the build matrix\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eRearrange OpenCV's build result, add our custom files and generate wheel\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eLinux and macOS wheels are transformed with auditwheel and delocate, correspondingly\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eInstall the generated wheel\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTest that Python can import the library and run some sanity checks\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eUse twine to upload the generated wheel to PyPI (only in release builds)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSteps 1--4 are handled by \u003ccode\u003epip wheel\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe build can be customized with environment variables. In addition to any variables that OpenCV's build accepts, we recognize:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003eCI_BUILD\u003c/code\u003e. Set to \u003ccode\u003e1\u003c/code\u003e to emulate the CI environment build behaviour. Used only in CI builds to force certain build flags on in \u003ccode\u003esetup.py\u003c/code\u003e. Do not use this unless you know what you are doing.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003eENABLE_CONTRIB\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003eENABLE_HEADLESS\u003c/code\u003e. Set to \u003ccode\u003e1\u003c/code\u003e to build the contrib and/or headless version\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003eENABLE_JAVA\u003c/code\u003e, Set to \u003ccode\u003e1\u003c/code\u003e to enable the Java client build.  This is disabled by default.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003eCMAKE_ARGS\u003c/code\u003e. Additional arguments for OpenCV's CMake invocation. You can use this to make a custom build.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSee the next section for more info about manual builds outside the CI environment.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eManual builds\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-manual-builds\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Manual builds\" href=\"#manual-builds\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf some dependency is not enabled in the pre-built wheels, you can also run the build locally to create a custom wheel.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eClone this repository: \u003ccode\u003egit clone --recursive https://github.com/opencv/opencv-python.git\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003ecd opencv-python\u003c/code\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eyou can use \u003ccode\u003egit\u003c/code\u003e to checkout some other version of OpenCV in the \u003ccode\u003eopencv\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003eopencv_contrib\u003c/code\u003e submodules if needed\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd custom Cmake flags if needed, for example: \u003ccode\u003eexport CMAKE_ARGS=\"-DSOME_FLAG=ON -DSOME_OTHER_FLAG=OFF\"\u003c/code\u003e (in Windows you need to set environment variables differently depending on Command Line or PowerShell)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSelect the package flavor which you wish to build with \u003ccode\u003eENABLE_CONTRIB\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003eENABLE_HEADLESS\u003c/code\u003e: i.e. \u003ccode\u003eexport ENABLE_CONTRIB=1\u003c/code\u003e if you wish to build \u003ccode\u003eopencv-contrib-python\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRun \u003ccode\u003epip wheel . --verbose\u003c/code\u003e. NOTE: make sure you have the latest \u003ccode\u003epip\u003c/code\u003e version, the \u003ccode\u003epip wheel\u003c/code\u003e command replaces the old \u003ccode\u003epython setup.py bdist_wheel\u003c/code\u003e command which does not support \u003ccode\u003epyproject.toml\u003c/code\u003e.\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ethis might take anything from 5 minutes to over 2 hours depending on your hardware\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePip will print fresh will location at the end of build procedure. If you use old approach with \u003ccode\u003esetup.py\u003c/code\u003e file wheel package will be placed in \u003ccode\u003edist\u003c/code\u003e folder. Package is ready and you can do with that whatever you wish.\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eOptional: on Linux use some of the \u003ccode\u003emanylinux\u003c/code\u003e images as a build hosts if maximum portability is needed and run \u003ccode\u003eauditwheel\u003c/code\u003e for the wheel after build\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eOptional: on macOS use \u003ccode\u003edelocate\u003c/code\u003e (same as \u003ccode\u003eauditwheel\u003c/code\u003e but for macOS) for better portability\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch4 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eIn order to build \u003ccode\u003eopencv-python\u003c/code\u003e in an unoptimized debug build, you need to side-step the normal process a bit.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eInstall the packages \u003ccode\u003escikit-build\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003enumpy\u003c/code\u003e via pip.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRun the command \u003ccode\u003epython setup.py bdist_wheel --build-type=Debug\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eInstall the generated wheel file in the \u003ccode\u003edist/\u003c/code\u003e folder with \u003ccode\u003epip install dist/wheelname.whl\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf you would like the build produce all compiler commands, then the following combination of flags and environment variables has been tested to work on Linux:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"export CMAKE_ARGS='-DCMAKE_VERBOSE_MAKEFILE=ON'\nexport VERBOSE=1\n\npython3 setup.py bdist_wheel --build-type=Debug\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003eexport CMAKE_ARGS='-DCMAKE_VERBOSE_MAKEFILE=ON'\nexport VERBOSE=1\n\npython3 setup.py bdist_wheel 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSince OpenCV version 4.3.0, also source distributions are provided in PyPI. This means that if your system is not compatible with any of the wheels in PyPI, \u003ccode\u003epip\u003c/code\u003e will attempt to build OpenCV from sources. If you need a OpenCV version which is not available in PyPI as a source distribution, please follow the manual build guidance above instead of this one.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eYou can also force \u003ccode\u003epip\u003c/code\u003e to build the wheels from the source distribution. Some examples:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003epip install --no-binary opencv-python opencv-python\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003epip install --no-binary :all: opencv-python\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf you need contrib modules or headless version, just change the package name (step 4 in the previous section is not needed). However, any additional CMake flags can be provided via environment variables as described in step 3 of the manual build section. If none are provided, OpenCV's CMake scripts will attempt to find and enable any suitable dependencies. Headless distributions have hard coded CMake flags which disable all possible GUI dependencies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eOn slow systems such as Raspberry Pi the full build may take several hours. On a 8-core Ryzen 7 3700X the build takes about 6 minutes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" It saves the version information to \u003ccode\u003eversion.py\u003c/code\u003e file under \u003ccode\u003ecv2\u003c/code\u003e in addition to some other flags.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eReleases\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-releases\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Releases\" href=\"#releases\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eA release is made and uploaded to PyPI when a new tag is pushed to master branch. These tags differentiate packages (this repo might have modifications but OpenCV version stays same) and should be incremented sequentially. In practice, release version numbers look like this:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003ecv_major.cv_minor.cv_revision.package_revision\u003c/code\u003e e.g. \u003ccode\u003e3.1.0.0\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe master branch follows OpenCV master branch releases. 3.4 branch follows OpenCV 3.4 bugfix releases.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eDevelopment builds\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-development-builds\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Development builds\" href=\"#development-builds\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eEvery commit to the master branch of this repo will be built. Possible build artifacts use local version identifiers:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003ecv_major.cv_minor.cv_revision+git_hash_of_this_repo\u003c/code\u003e e.g. \u003ccode\u003e3.1.0+14a8d39\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThese artifacts can't be and will not be uploaded to PyPI.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eManylinux wheels\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-manylinux-wheels\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Manylinux wheels\" href=\"#manylinux-wheels\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eLinux wheels are built using \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/pypa/manylinux\"\u003emanylinux2014\u003c/a\u003e. 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><ol dir="auto"><li><p dir="auto">If you have previous/other manually installed (= not installed via <code>pip</code>) version of OpenCV installed (e.g. cv2 module in the root of Python's site-packages), remove it before installation to avoid conflicts.</p></li><li><p dir="auto">Make sure that your <code>pip</code> version is up-to-date (19.3 is the minimum supported version): <code>pip install --upgrade pip</code>. Check version with <code>pip -V</code>. For example Linux distributions ship usually with very old <code>pip</code> versions which cause a lot of unexpected problems especially with the <code>manylinux</code> format.</p></li><li><p dir="auto">Select the correct package for your environment:</p><p dir="auto">There are four different packages (see options 1, 2, 3 and 4 below) and you should <strong>SELECT ONLY ONE OF THEM</strong>. Do not install multiple different packages in the same environment. There is no plugin architecture: all the packages use the same namespace (<code>cv2</code>). If you installed multiple different packages in the same environment, uninstall them all with <code>pip uninstall</code> and reinstall only one package.</p><p dir="auto"><strong>a.</strong> Packages for standard desktop environments (Windows, macOS, almost any GNU/Linux distribution)</p><ul dir="auto"><li>Option 1 - Main modules package: <code>pip install opencv-python</code></li><li>Option 2 - Full package (contains both main modules and contrib/extra modules): <code>pip install opencv-contrib-python</code> (check contrib/extra modules listing from <a href="https://docs.opencv.org/master/" rel="nofollow">OpenCV documentation</a>)</li></ul><p dir="auto"><strong>b.</strong> Packages for server (headless) environments (such as Docker, cloud environments etc.), no GUI library dependencies</p><p dir="auto">These packages are smaller than the two other packages above because they do not contain any GUI functionality (not compiled with Qt / other GUI components). This means that the packages avoid a heavy dependency chain to X11 libraries and you will have for example smaller Docker images as a result. You should always use these packages if you do not use <code>cv2.imshow</code> et al. or you are using some other package (such as PyQt) than OpenCV to create your GUI.</p><ul dir="auto"><li>Option 3 - Headless main modules package: <code>pip install opencv-python-headless</code></li><li>Option 4 - Headless full package (contains both main modules and contrib/extra modules): <code>pip install opencv-contrib-python-headless</code> (check contrib/extra modules listing from <a href="https://docs.opencv.org/master/" rel="nofollow">OpenCV documentation</a>)</li></ul></li><li><p dir="auto">Import the package:</p><p dir="auto"><code>import cv2</code></p><p dir="auto">All packages contain Haar cascade files. <code>cv2.data.haarcascades</code> can be used as a shortcut to the data folder. For example:</p><p dir="auto"><code>cv2.CascadeClassifier(cv2.data.haarcascades + "haarcascade_frontalface_default.xml")</code></p></li><li><p dir="auto">Read <a href="https://docs.opencv.org/master/" rel="nofollow">OpenCV documentation</a></p></li><li><p dir="auto">Before opening a new issue, read the FAQ below and have a look at the other issues which are already open.</p></li></ol><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Frequently Asked Questions</h2><a id="user-content-frequently-asked-questions" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Frequently Asked Questions" href="#frequently-asked-questions"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto"><strong>Q: Do I need to install also OpenCV separately?</strong></p><p dir="auto">A: No, the packages are special wheel binary packages and they already contain statically built OpenCV binaries.</p><p dir="auto"><strong>Q: Pip install fails with <code>ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'skbuild'</code>?</strong></p><p dir="auto">Since <code>opencv-python</code> version 4.3.0.*, <code>manylinux1</code> wheels were replaced by <code>manylinux2014</code> wheels. If your pip is too old, it will try to use the new source distribution introduced in 4.3.0.38 to manually build OpenCV because it does not know how to install <code>manylinux2014</code> wheels. However, source build will also fail because of too old <code>pip</code> because it does not understand build dependencies in <code>pyproject.toml</code>. To use the new <code>manylinux2014</code> pre-built wheels (or to build from source), your <code>pip</code> version must be >= 19.3. Please upgrade <code>pip</code> with <code>pip install --upgrade pip</code>.</p><p dir="auto"><strong>Q: Import fails on Windows: <code>ImportError: DLL load failed: The specified module could not be found.</code>?</strong></p><p dir="auto">A: If the import fails on Windows, make sure you have <a href="https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=48145" rel="nofollow">Visual C++ redistributable 2015</a> installed. If you are using older Windows version than Windows 10 and latest system updates are not installed, <a href="https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/2999226/update-for-universal-c-runtime-in-windows" rel="nofollow">Universal C Runtime</a> might be also required.</p><p dir="auto">Windows N and KN editions do not include Media Feature Pack which is required by OpenCV. If you are using Windows N or KN edition, please install also <a href="https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/3145500/media-feature-pack-list-for-windows-n-editions" rel="nofollow">Windows Media Feature Pack</a>.</p><p dir="auto">If you have Windows Server 2012+, media DLLs are probably missing too; please install the Feature called "Media Foundation" in the Server Manager. Beware, some posts advise to install "Windows Server Essentials Media Pack", but this one requires the "Windows Server Essentials Experience" role, and this role will deeply affect your Windows Server configuration (by enforcing active directory integration etc.); so just installing the "Media Foundation" should be a safer choice.</p><p dir="auto">If the above does not help, check if you are using Anaconda. Old Anaconda versions have a bug which causes the error, see <a href="https://github.com/opencv/opencv-python/issues/36" data-hovercard-type="issue" data-hovercard-url="/opencv/opencv-python/issues/36/hovercard">this issue</a> for a manual fix.</p><p dir="auto">If you still encounter the error after you have checked all the previous solutions, download <a href="https://github.com/lucasg/Dependencies">Dependencies</a> and open the <code>cv2.pyd</code> (located usually at <code>C:\Users\username\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\PythonXX\Lib\site-packages\cv2</code>) file with it to debug missing DLL issues.</p><p dir="auto"><strong>Q: I have some other import errors?</strong></p><p dir="auto">A: Make sure you have removed old manual installations of OpenCV Python bindings (cv2.so or cv2.pyd in site-packages).</p><p dir="auto"><strong>Q: Function foo() or method bar() returns wrong result, throws exception or crashes interpreter. What should I do?</strong></p><p dir="auto">A: The repository contains only OpenCV-Python package build scripts, but not OpenCV itself. Python bindings for OpenCV are developed in official OpenCV repository and it's the best place to report issues. Also please check <a href="https://github.com/opencv/opencv/wiki">OpenCV wiki</a> and <a href="https://forum.opencv.org/" rel="nofollow">the official OpenCV forum</a> before file new bugs.</p><p dir="auto"><strong>Q: Why the packages do not include non-free algorithms?</strong></p><p dir="auto">A: Non-free algorithms such as SURF are not included in these packages because they are patented / non-free and therefore cannot be distributed as built binaries. Note that SIFT is included in the builds due to patent expiration since OpenCV versions 4.3.0 and 3.4.10. See this issue for more info: <a class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-error-text="Failed to load title" data-id="359347266" data-permission-text="Title is private" data-url="https://github.com/opencv/opencv-python/issues/126" data-hovercard-type="issue" data-hovercard-url="/opencv/opencv-python/issues/126/hovercard" href="https://github.com/opencv/opencv-python/issues/126">#126</a></p><p dir="auto"><strong>Q: Why the package and import are different (opencv-python vs. cv2)?</strong></p><p dir="auto">A: It's easier for users to understand <code>opencv-python</code> than <code>cv2</code> and it makes it easier to find the package with search engines. <code>cv2</code> (old interface in old OpenCV versions was named as <code>cv</code>) is the name that OpenCV developers chose when they created the binding generators. This is kept as the import name to be consistent with different kind of tutorials around the internet. Changing the import name or behaviour would be also confusing to experienced users who are accustomed to the <code>import cv2</code>.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Documentation for opencv-python</h2><a id="user-content-documentation-for-opencv-python" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Documentation for opencv-python" href="#documentation-for-opencv-python"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 href="https://github.com/opencv/opencv-python/actions/workflows/build_wheels_windows.yml"><img src="https://github.com/opencv/opencv-python/actions/workflows/build_wheels_windows.yml/badge.svg" alt="Windows Build Status" style="max-width: 100%;"></a><a href="https://github.com/opencv/opencv-python/actions/workflows/build_wheels_linux.yml"><img src="https://github.com/opencv/opencv-python/actions/workflows/build_wheels_linux.yml/badge.svg" alt="(Linux Build status)" style="max-width: 100%;"></a><a href="https://github.com/opencv/opencv-python/actions/workflows/build_wheels_macos.yml"><img src="https://github.com/opencv/opencv-python/actions/workflows/build_wheels_macos.yml/badge.svg" alt="(Mac OS Build status)" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></p><p dir="auto">The aim of this repository is to provide means to package each new <a href="https://github.com/opencv/opencv/releases">OpenCV release</a> for the most used Python versions and platforms.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">CI build process</h3><a id="user-content-ci-build-process" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: CI build process" href="#ci-build-process"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">The project is structured like a normal Python package with a standard <code>setup.py</code> file.The build process for a single entry in the build matrices is as follows (see for example <code>.github/workflows/build_wheels_linux.yml</code> file):</p><ol start="0" dir="auto"><li><p dir="auto">In Linux and MacOS build: get OpenCV's optional C dependencies that we compile against</p></li><li><p dir="auto">Checkout repository and submodules</p><ul dir="auto"><li>OpenCV is included as submodule and the version is updatedmanually by maintainers when a new OpenCV release has been made</li><li>Contrib modules are also included as a submodule</li></ul></li><li><p dir="auto">Find OpenCV version from the sources</p></li><li><p dir="auto">Build OpenCV</p><ul dir="auto"><li>tests are disabled, otherwise build time increases too much</li><li>there are 4 build matrix entries for each build combination: with and without contrib modules, with and without GUI (headless)</li><li>Linux builds run in manylinux Docker containers (CentOS 5)</li><li>source distributions are separate entries in the build matrix</li></ul></li><li><p dir="auto">Rearrange OpenCV's build result, add our custom files and generate wheel</p></li><li><p dir="auto">Linux and macOS wheels are transformed with auditwheel and delocate, correspondingly</p></li><li><p dir="auto">Install the generated wheel</p></li><li><p dir="auto">Test that Python can import the library and run some sanity checks</p></li><li><p dir="auto">Use twine to upload the generated wheel to PyPI (only in release builds)</p></li></ol><p dir="auto">Steps 1--4 are handled by <code>pip wheel</code>.</p><p dir="auto">The build can be customized with environment variables. In addition to any variables that OpenCV's build accepts, we recognize:</p><ul dir="auto"><li><code>CI_BUILD</code>. Set to <code>1</code> to emulate the CI environment build behaviour. Used only in CI builds to force certain build flags on in <code>setup.py</code>. Do not use this unless you know what you are doing.</li><li><code>ENABLE_CONTRIB</code> and <code>ENABLE_HEADLESS</code>. Set to <code>1</code> to build the contrib and/or headless version</li><li><code>ENABLE_JAVA</code>, Set to <code>1</code> to enable the Java client build.  This is disabled by default.</li><li><code>CMAKE_ARGS</code>. Additional arguments for OpenCV's CMake invocation. You can use this to make a custom build.</li></ul><p dir="auto">See the next section for more info about manual builds outside the CI environment.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Manual builds</h3><a id="user-content-manual-builds" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Manual builds" href="#manual-builds"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">If some dependency is not enabled in the pre-built wheels, you can also run the build locally to create a custom wheel.</p><ol dir="auto"><li>Clone this repository: <code>git clone --recursive https://github.com/opencv/opencv-python.git</code></li><li><code>cd opencv-python</code><ul dir="auto"><li>you can use <code>git</code> to checkout some other version of OpenCV in the <code>opencv</code> and <code>opencv_contrib</code> submodules if needed</li></ul></li><li>Add custom Cmake flags if needed, for example: <code>export CMAKE_ARGS="-DSOME_FLAG=ON -DSOME_OTHER_FLAG=OFF"</code> (in Windows you need to set environment variables differently depending on Command Line or PowerShell)</li><li>Select the package flavor which you wish to build with <code>ENABLE_CONTRIB</code> and <code>ENABLE_HEADLESS</code>: i.e. <code>export ENABLE_CONTRIB=1</code> if you wish to build <code>opencv-contrib-python</code></li><li>Run <code>pip wheel . --verbose</code>. NOTE: make sure you have the latest <code>pip</code> version, the <code>pip wheel</code> command replaces the old <code>python setup.py bdist_wheel</code> command which does not support <code>pyproject.toml</code>.<ul dir="auto"><li>this might take anything from 5 minutes to over 2 hours depending on your hardware</li></ul></li><li>Pip will print fresh will location at the end of build procedure. If you use old approach with <code>setup.py</code> file wheel package will be placed in <code>dist</code> folder. Package is ready and you can do with that whatever you wish.<ul dir="auto"><li>Optional: on Linux use some of the <code>manylinux</code> images as a build hosts if maximum portability is needed and run <code>auditwheel</code> for the wheel after build</li><li>Optional: on macOS use <code>delocate</code> (same as <code>auditwheel</code> but for macOS) for better portability</li></ul></li></ol><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h4 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Manual debug builds</h4><a id="user-content-manual-debug-builds" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Manual debug builds" href="#manual-debug-builds"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">In order to build <code>opencv-python</code> in an unoptimized debug build, you need to side-step the normal process a bit.</p><ol dir="auto"><li>Install the packages <code>scikit-build</code> and <code>numpy</code> via pip.</li><li>Run the command <code>python setup.py bdist_wheel --build-type=Debug</code>.</li><li>Install the generated wheel file in the <code>dist/</code> folder with <code>pip install dist/wheelname.whl</code>.</li></ol><p dir="auto">If you would like the build produce all compiler commands, then the following combination of flags and environment variables has been tested to work on Linux:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="export CMAKE_ARGS='-DCMAKE_VERBOSE_MAKEFILE=ON'export VERBOSE=1python3 setup.py bdist_wheel --build-type=Debug"><pre class="notranslate"><code>export CMAKE_ARGS='-DCMAKE_VERBOSE_MAKEFILE=ON'export VERBOSE=1python3 setup.py bdist_wheel --build-type=Debug</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">See this issue for more discussion: <a class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-error-text="Failed to load title" data-id="756059775" data-permission-text="Title is private" data-url="https://github.com/opencv/opencv-python/issues/424" data-hovercard-type="issue" data-hovercard-url="/opencv/opencv-python/issues/424/hovercard" href="https://github.com/opencv/opencv-python/issues/424">#424</a></p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h4 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Source distributions</h4><a id="user-content-source-distributions" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Source distributions" href="#source-distributions"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">Since OpenCV version 4.3.0, also source distributions are provided in PyPI. This means that if your system is not compatible with any of the wheels in PyPI, <code>pip</code> will attempt to build OpenCV from sources. If you need a OpenCV version which is not available in PyPI as a source distribution, please follow the manual build guidance above instead of this one.</p><p dir="auto">You can also force <code>pip</code> to build the wheels from the source distribution. Some examples:</p><ul dir="auto"><li><code>pip install --no-binary opencv-python opencv-python</code></li><li><code>pip install --no-binary :all: opencv-python</code></li></ul><p dir="auto">If you need contrib modules or headless version, just change the package name (step 4 in the previous section is not needed). However, any additional CMake flags can be provided via environment variables as described in step 3 of the manual build section. If none are provided, OpenCV's CMake scripts will attempt to find and enable any suitable dependencies. Headless distributions have hard coded CMake flags which disable all possible GUI dependencies.</p><p dir="auto">On slow systems such as Raspberry Pi the full build may take several hours. On a 8-core Ryzen 7 3700X the build takes about 6 minutes.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Licensing</h3><a id="user-content-licensing" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Licensing" href="#licensing"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">Opencv-python package (scripts in this repository) is available under MIT license.</p><p dir="auto">OpenCV itself is available under <a href="https://github.com/opencv/opencv/blob/master/LICENSE">Apache 2</a> license.</p><p dir="auto">Third party package licenses are at <a href="https://github.com/opencv/opencv-python/blob/master/LICENSE-3RD-PARTY.txt">LICENSE-3RD-PARTY.txt</a>.</p><p dir="auto">All wheels ship with <a href="http://ffmpeg.org" rel="nofollow">FFmpeg</a> licensed under the <a href="http://www.gnu.org/licenses/old-licenses/lgpl-2.1.html" rel="nofollow">LGPLv2.1</a>.</p><p dir="auto">Non-headless Linux wheels ship with <a href="http://doc.qt.io/qt-5/lgpl.html" rel="nofollow">Qt 5</a> licensed under the <a href="http://www.gnu.org/licenses/lgpl-3.0.html" rel="nofollow">LGPLv3</a>.</p><p dir="auto">The packages include also other binaries. Full list of licenses can be found from <a href="https://github.com/opencv/opencv-python/blob/master/LICENSE-3RD-PARTY.txt">LICENSE-3RD-PARTY.txt</a>.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Versioning</h3><a id="user-content-versioning" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Versioning" href="#versioning"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto"><code>find_version.py</code> script searches for the version information from OpenCV sources and appends also a revision number specific to this repository to the version string. It saves the version information to <code>version.py</code> file under <code>cv2</code> in addition to some other flags.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Releases</h3><a id="user-content-releases" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Releases" href="#releases"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">A release is made and uploaded to PyPI when a new tag is pushed to master branch. These tags differentiate packages (this repo might have modifications but OpenCV version stays same) and should be incremented sequentially. In practice, release version numbers look like this:</p><p dir="auto"><code>cv_major.cv_minor.cv_revision.package_revision</code> e.g. <code>3.1.0.0</code></p><p dir="auto">The master branch follows OpenCV master branch releases. 3.4 branch follows OpenCV 3.4 bugfix releases.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Development builds</h3><a id="user-content-development-builds" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Development builds" href="#development-builds"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">Every commit to the master branch of this repo will be built. Possible build artifacts use local version identifiers:</p><p dir="auto"><code>cv_major.cv_minor.cv_revision+git_hash_of_this_repo</code> e.g. <code>3.1.0+14a8d39</code></p><p dir="auto">These artifacts can't be and will not be uploaded to PyPI.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Manylinux wheels</h3><a id="user-content-manylinux-wheels" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Manylinux wheels" href="#manylinux-wheels"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">Linux wheels are built using <a href="https://github.com/pypa/manylinux">manylinux2014</a>. These wheels should work out of the box for most of the distros (which use GNU C standard library) out there since they are built against an old version of glibc.</p><p dir="auto">The default <code>manylinux2014</code> images have been extended with some OpenCV dependencies. See <a href="https://github.com/skvark/opencv-python/tree/master/docker">Docker folder</a> for more info.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element"
